author: jgm
content: Is it legal for a validator to aggregate its own attestations prior to broadcasting them, regardless of if it is an "official" aggregator for that (slot,committee)?

author: ajsutton
content: <@!144468805697929216> It is not legal to publish any aggregated attestation on the subnet topics, they must have a single validator only. And I think the global one requires SignedAggregateAndProof messages.  So no.

author: jgm
content: <@!340345049063882753> any idea why that restriction is in place?  If my validator is generating a number of attestations for the same (slot,committee) it seems a waste of bandwidth and computation to send each individually.

author: ajsutton
content: Yes I was planning to just send aggregates as well. I guess the one advantage is that it limits the amount of gossip going around. Otherwise a node could aggregate and broadcast a huge number of different attestations to swamp the network. Whereas with these rules thereâ€™s a much more limited number of unique messages that can be sent and they have to come from the actual validator not just someone who collected and aggregated them in different ways.

author: jgm
content: True, although you could probably manage that with some sort of peer scoring.  The all or nothing approach to subnets does feel very inefficient at scale.
